training_philosophy: Specificity, progressive overload, and systematic finger strength development
evidence_base: Elite climber training protocols and climbing-specific research

exercises.scientific_explanation: Maximum hangs develop finger strength through recruitment of high-threshold motor units. Research with elite climbers shows 20-30% strength gains when performed 2-3x weekly. Hörst's protocol uses 7-second max hangs with 3-minute rest to optimize strength adaptation while preventing overuse injury.
research_citations: MacLeod et al. (2007): Finger strength and climbing performance
Medernach et al. (2015): Hangboard training effects
exercises.performance_metrics: 7-second max hang, smallest hold possible, body weight + additional load
exercises.form_cue: Engage shoulders, slight bend in arms, breathe normally during hang
exercises.common_mistake: Hanging on holds too large or not engaging proper shoulder position

progression_protocol.advanced: Small holds, added weight, 7 seconds max

exercises.scientific_explanation: Campus board training develops contact strength and dynamic finger power essential for hard climbing moves. Research shows improvements in rate of force development and dynamic pulling power when performed systematically. The Anderson protocol emphasizes progressive ladder sequences.
research_citations: MacLeod et al. (2012): Dynamic finger strength
Baláš et al. (2016): Power training in climbing
exercises.performance_metrics: Ladder progression (1-4-7, 1-5-8, etc.), dynamic movement quality
exercises.form_cue: Explosive pull to next hold, dead hang briefly, continue ladder
exercises.common_mistake: Starting with holds too small or advancing progression too quickly

exercises.scientific_explanation: Push-ups counteract the pulling dominance of climbing by strengthening the anterior chain. Research shows 40% reduction in shoulder and elbow overuse injuries in climbers who perform regular antagonist training. Essential for maintaining shoulder health and preventing muscular imbalances.
research_citations: Josephsen et al. (2007): Climbing injury prevention
Schöffl et al. (2010): Overuse injuries in climbing
exercises.performance_metrics: 2:1 ratio with pulling exercises, controlled tempo
exercises.form_cue: Perfect push-up form, focus on full range of motion
exercises.common_mistake: Neglecting antagonist training or poor push-up form

exercises.scientific_explanation: Core tension exercises mimic the sustained isometric demands of climbing while developing the ability to maintain body position on steep terrain. Research shows core strength directly correlates with climbing performance, particularly on overhanging routes.
exercises.form_cue: Maintain tight core while breathing normally
exercises.common_mistake: Holding breath or not maintaining tension throughout hold

exercises.scientific_explanation: Finger flexibility work prevents contractures and maintains range of motion essential for varied hold types. Research demonstrates reduced incidence of finger injuries and improved crimping ability when flexibility is maintained through systematic stretching.
research_citations: Logan et al. (2004): Climbing injury patterns
exercises.performance_metrics: Hold stretches 30-60 seconds, multiple finger positions
exercises.form_cue: Gentle sustained stretch, no bouncing or forcing
